hypothesis: Vice President Biden and President Obama assembled a pandemic playbook to make sure that America was prepared and protected. The Trump administration disbanded the pandemic response team that was given to them.
explanation_1: It seems from the 3rd QA that the group was indeed disbanded therefore the claim is supported
speaker: Eva Longoria Bastón

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: Through the Obama administration, the NSC devised the guide — officially called the Playbook for Early Response to High-Consequence Emerging Infectious Disease Threats and Biological Incidents, but known colloquially as "the pandemic playbook" — across 2016. The project was driven by career civil servants as well as political appointees, aware that global leaders had initially fumbled their response to the 2014–2015 spread of Ebola and wanting to be sure that the next response to an epidemic was better handled.

questions.question: Did Vice President Biden and President Obama assemble a pandemic playbook to make sure that America was prepared and protected?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: The Trump administration was briefed on the playbook’s existence in 2017, said four former officials, but two cautioned that it never went through a full, National Security Council-led interagency process to be approved as Trump administration strategy.

questions.question: Did President Donald Trump utilize the pandemic playbook?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: The document rested with NSC officials who dealt with medical preparedness and biodefense in the global health security directorate, which the Trump administration disbanded in 2018, four former officials said.

questions.question: Did President Donald Trump disband the pandemic response team that was given to him?

answers.answer: “We are aware of the document, although it’s quite dated and has been superseded by strategic and operational biodefense policies published since,” the official said. “The plan we are executing now is a better fit, more detailed, and applies the relevant lessons learned from the playbook and the most recent Ebola epidemic in the [Democratic Republic of the Congo] to COVID-19.”

questions.question: Why did the Trump administration not utilize the pandemic playbook?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: a president can choose cabinent members he chooses to work with

questions.question: is it normal for  a new president to set up their own working team

premise:
Question 1:  Did Vice President Biden and President Obama assemble a pandemic playbook to make sure that America was prepared and protected? 
Answer 1:  Yes 
 
Question 2:  Did President Donald Trump utilize the pandemic playbook? 
Answer 2:  No 
 
Question 3:  Did President Donald Trump disband the pandemic response team that was given to him? 
Answer 3:  Yes 
 
Question 4:  Why did the Trump administration not utilize the pandemic playbook? 
Answer 4:  “We are aware of the document, although it’s quite dated and has been superseded by strategic and operational biodefense policies published since,” the official said. “The plan we are executing now is a better fit, more detailed, and applies the relevant lessons learned from the playbook and the most recent Ebola epidemic in the [Democratic Republic of the Congo] to COVID-19.” 
 
Question 5:  is it normal for  a new president to set up their own working team 
Answer 5:  Yes

hypothesis: More than 500 scientists and professionals in climate and related fields have sent a "European Climate Declaration" to the Secretary-General of the United Nations.
explanation_1: Evidence shows that the 500 aren't even experts in climate change and according to a source the credibility is low
speaker: 500 scientists

answers.answer:
Amber Kerr, Researcher, Agricultural Sustainability Institute, University of California, Davis:
While reviewing the claims related to agriculture, I noted that only 26 out of the 506 signatories (5%) were professionals in biology, ecology, or environmental science. I suspect that the vast majority of signatories had little direct knowledge or understanding of this part of the petition that they signed.

questions.question: How many of the 500 signatures are scientists?

answers.answer: The most prevalent groups of signatories were geologists (19%) and engineers (21%)—many of whom were implicitly or explicitly involved in fossil energy extraction. Most of the rest were physicists, chemists, and mathematicians.

questions.question: What were the prevalent fields of expertise within the signatures?
How many signatures were not scientists?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: “Peter Champness, Radiologist, Australia”; “Patrick Mellett, architect and CEO”; and “Fintan Ryan, Retired Senior Airline Captain” (to say nothing of the dozens and dozens of fossil fuel employees)

questions.question: Were there any signatories with credentials?

answers.answer:
Amber Kerr, Researcher, Agricultural Sustainability Institute, University of California, Davis:
While reviewing the claims related to agriculture, I noted that only 26 out of the 506 signatories (5%) were professionals in biology, ecology, or environmental science. I suspect that the vast majority of signatories had little direct knowledge or understanding of this part of the petition that they signed.

questions.question: How many of the signatories are scientists?

answers.answer:
The Washington Times - Sunday, September 29, 2019 published an article on the event.

Scientists tell U.N. Global Climate Summit: No emergency

Climate Intelligence Foundation calls for UN meeting with experts from both sides of debate

 ....last week’s U.N. Global Climate Summit were the 500 international scientists, engineers and other stakeholders sounding a very different message: “There is no climate emergency.”

The signers asked Mr. Guterres to place the declaration on the UN’s agenda for the meeting ending Monday—which hasn’t happened—and organize a meeting of scientists “on both sides of the climate debate early in 2020.”

The Independent UK published on Wednesday 25 September 2019 :

Hundreds of climate change deniers including academics, politicians and lobbyists are to launch a campaign to stop commitments to net zero carbon emissions being enshrined in law, The Independent can reveal.

A letter titled “There is no climate emergency” – which has been signed by 400 people who deem climate change to be a myth – is being sent to leaders of European Union (EU) and United Nations (UN) institutions in the coming weeks ahead of key environment talks.

questions.question: What did the media report about the claim that more than 500 scientists and professionals in climate and related fields have sent a 'European Climate Declaration' to the Secretary-General of the United Nations.?

answers.answer: The European Climate Declaration was spearheaded by the Amsterdam-based Climate Intelligence Foundation [CLINTEL].

questions.question: Who was responsible for the declaration letter?

answers.answer: The letter has been criticized by six scientists who claim that its credibility is very low. One complaint is that most of the 500 are not experts in "climate science."

The letter uses the phrasing "more than 500 knowledgeable and experienced scientists and professionals in climate and related fields". Not all are "scientists" as per the title that the OP wrote. As seen above, one person is simply listed as being an "author" and another is listed as "PhD in Law, author of several books".

...the sheer number of prominent signers with scientific and engineering credentials belied the contention that only a handful of fringe researchers and fossil-fuel shills oppose the climate-catastrophe “consensus.”

The U.S. contingent was made up of 45 U.S. professors, engineers and scientists, including MIT professor emeritus Richard Lindzen; Freeman Dyson of the Institute of Advanced Studies at Princeton, and Stanford University professor emeritus Elliott D. Bloom, as well as several signers formerly affiliated with NASA.

questions.question: What credibility has been placed on the declaration?

premise:

Answer 1:  Amber Kerr, Researcher, Agricultural Sustainability Institute, University of California, Davis:
While reviewing the claims related to agriculture, I noted that only 26 out of the 506 signatories (5%) were professionals in biology, ecology, or environmental science. I suspect that the vast majority of signatories had little direct knowledge or understanding of this part of the petition that they signed. 
 
Question 2:  What were the prevalent fields of expertise within the signatures? 
Answer 2:  The most prevalent groups of signatories were geologists (19%) and engineers (21%)—many of whom were implicitly or explicitly involved in fossil energy extraction. Most of the rest were physicists, chemists, and mathematicians. 
 
Question 3:  How many signatures were not scientists? 
Answer 3:  11.3% 
 
Question 4:  Were there any signatories with credentials? 
Answer 4:  Yes 
 
Question 5:  How many of the signatories are scientists? 
Answer 5:  Amber Kerr, Researcher, Agricultural Sustainability Institute, University of California, Davis:
While reviewing the claims related to agriculture, I noted that only 26 out of the 506 signatories (5%) were professionals in biology, ecology, or environmental science. I suspect that the vast majority of signatories had little direct knowledge or understanding of this part of the petition that they signed. 
 
Question 6:  What did the media report about the claim that more than 500 scientists and professionals in climate and related fields have sent a 'European Climate Declaration' to the Secretary-General of the United Nations.? 
Answer 6:  The Washington Times - Sunday, September 29, 2019 published an article on the event.

Scientists tell U.N. Global Climate Summit: No emergency

Climate Intelligence Foundation calls for UN meeting with experts from both sides of debate

 ....last week’s U.N. Global Climate Summit were the 500 international scientists, engineers and other stakeholders sounding a very different message: “There is no climate emergency.”

The signers asked Mr. Guterres to place the declaration on the UN’s agenda for the meeting ending Monday—which hasn’t happened—and organize a meeting of scientists “on both sides of the climate debate early in 2020.” The Independent UK published on Wednesday 25 September 2019 :

Hundreds of climate change deniers including academics, politicians and lobbyists are to launch a campaign to stop commitments to net zero carbon emissions being enshrined in law, The Independent can reveal.

A letter titled “There is no climate emergency” – which has been signed by 400 people who deem climate change to be a myth – is being sent to leaders of European Union (EU) and United Nations (UN) institutions in the coming weeks ahead of key environment talks. 
 
Question 7:  Who was responsible for the declaration letter? 
Answer 7:  The European Climate Declaration was spearheaded by the Amsterdam-based Climate Intelligence Foundation [CLINTEL]. 
 
Question 8:  What credibility has been placed on the declaration? 
Answer 8:  The letter has been criticized by six scientists who claim that its credibility is very low. One complaint is that most of the 500 are not experts in "climate science." The letter uses the phrasing "more than 500 knowledgeable and experienced scientists and professionals in climate and related fields". Not all are "scientists" as per the title that the OP wrote. As seen above, one person is simply listed as being an "author" and another is listed as "PhD in Law, author of several books". ...the sheer number of prominent signers with scientific and engineering credentials belied the contention that only a handful of fringe researchers and fossil-fuel shills oppose the climate-catastrophe “consensus.”

The U.S. contingent was made up of 45 U.S. professors, engineers and scientists, including MIT professor emeritus Richard Lindzen; Freeman Dyson of the Institute of Advanced Studies at Princeton, and Stanford University professor emeritus Elliott D. Bloom, as well as several signers formerly affiliated with NASA.

questions.question: What quote of Gandhi did Professor Bakker refer to which is thematically related?

answers.answer: This website records the investigatory work of Garson O’Toole who diligently seeks the truth about quotations. Who really said what? This question often cannot be answered with complete finality, but approximate solutions can be iteratively improved over time.

questions.question: What is the website Quote Investigator?

answers.answer:
Quote Investigator: Gandhi died in 1948, and the earliest close match known to QI appeared many years later in 1974 within a book chapter written by educator Arleen Lorrance. She described her unhappiness while employed at a high school in Brooklyn, New York:[1]
 ...be the change you want to see happen.

hypothesis: US Senator Amy Klobuchar said While we are all sitting here debating, Wisconsin has kicked hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls
explanation_1: yes, wisconsin has removed people who didn't update their address details, but not random people, the answers showed no evidence that people were unlawfully removed.
speaker: Amy Klobuchar

answers.answer: Wisconsin appeals court rules voters targeted for purge will remain on the rolls

questions.question: Did the US state of Wisconsin purge hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls in 2020

answers.answer:
The Wisconsin Elections Commission last month sent letters to voters who it believes may have moved. The letters told the recipients to update their voter registrations with their new addresses if they have moved or to notify the commission if they have not moved.

Those who don't act on the letters will have their voter registrations suspended after April 2021, according to the commission.

questions.question: Why did the Wisconsin Election Commission send letters to 234,000 voters warning them they may be removed from polls in 2021?

answers.answer:
A Wisconsin appeals court Friday struck down an Ozaukee County judge's ruling that thousands of people had to be quickly removed from the state's voter rolls because they are believed to have moved.

The appeals judges also unanimously overturned a finding that state election officials were in contempt of court for not taking people off the rolls.

questions.question: What did the Wisconsin court rule about the election commission?

premise:
Question 1:  Did the US state of Wisconsin purge hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls in 2020 
Answer 1:  Wisconsin appeals court rules voters targeted for purge will remain on the rolls 
 
Question 2:  Why did the Wisconsin Election Commission send letters to 234,000 voters warning them they may be removed from polls in 2021? 
Answer 2:  The Wisconsin Elections Commission last month sent letters to voters who it believes may have moved. The letters told the recipients to update their voter registrations with their new addresses if they have moved or to notify the commission if they have not moved.

Those who don't act on the letters will have their voter registrations suspended after April 2021, according to the commission. 
 
Question 3:  What did the Wisconsin court rule about the election commission? 
Answer 3:  A Wisconsin appeals court Friday struck down an Ozaukee County judge's ruling that thousands of people had to be quickly removed from the state's voter rolls because they are believed to have moved.

The appeals judges also unanimously overturned a finding that state election officials were in contempt of court for not taking people off the rolls.
